description.narrative: Cambodia Climate Change Alliance (CCCA)

title.narrative: Mid Term Review Report of Cambodia Climate Change Alliance project

description.narrative: Cambodia Climate Change Alliance Phase 2

1. National M&E Framework is approved and functional including gender disaggregated and poverty indicators 2. Number of ministries with institutional arrangement to manage their Climate Change Action Plan (CCAP) and contribute to Climate Change Technical Team (CCTT) activities 3. Number of ministries that demonstrate capacity to implement at least 50% actions in their CCAPs and report on CCAP progress in line with national standards (incl. gender analysis) 4. Legal mandates for the National Climate Change Committee (NCCC), CCTT and NCCC secretariat strengthened

comment.narrative: Baseline 2013 1. A draft M&E Framework is under discussion 2. 2 3. 0 4. Institutional and legal review is on-going
1. National level indicators approved and baselines established 2. 3 3. 0 4. New royal decree and sub decree drafted

1. Indicators and baselines are ready to be launched. 2. 3 (Ministry of Agriculture Forestry and Fisheries, Ministry of Women's Affairs and Ministry of Rural Development have established working groups in charge of climate change issues, under senior leadership). 3. 0 4. Royal Decree and Sub-Decree on the National Council for Sustainable Development and its General Secretariat adopted in May 2015.

description.narrative: Strengthening sustainable forest management and bio-energy markets to promote environmental sustainability and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Cambodia

title.narrative: Strengthening sustainable forest management and bio-energy markets to promote environment sustainability and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in Cambodia

description.narrative: Strengthening sustainable forest management, through integrating community-based sustainable forest management into policy, planning and investment frameworks and creating markets for sustainable bio-energy technologies which reduce CO2 emissions

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. 30 (25 females) new Improved Cook Stove (ICS) Producers Selected and trained on ICS technical production skills 3. 0

1. 30 Community Forestry (CF); 10 Community Protected Area (CPA) completed the CF/CPA Management Plan.
2. 90,000 units of Improved Cook Stove (ICK) sold and 06 ICS production centres installed.
3. 100 new job created

1. 30 Community Forestry (CF) (10,879 ha) completed the Community Forestry Management Plan (CFMP) and Community Forestry Business Plan (CFBP). 11 Community Protected Area (CPA) (8,991 ha) completed the draft CPA MP. Some CF and CPA already started pilot implementation of the management and forest-based enterprises.
2. 143,575 units of ICS sold from the eight (08) newly established ICS production centres.
3. 45 ICS production units, which employed 180 craftsmen (130 women).

description.narrative:
Deforestation rate in protected forests in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhnang, Battambang and Pursat provinces.
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Trend in deforestation rates for 4 years before start of project in FA and MoE forests in target provinces.
[Revised]

Average deforestation rate in FA and MoE forests are 10% lower than rates in 4 years preceding project.
[Revised]

Zero Deforestation at target sites.
The current deforestation rate in the target sites is -0.46% per year; and the deforestation rate at the national level was 0.5% per year (baseline); indicating that there is no deforestation rate in the target sites. However, the deforestation rate in the target provinces is +0.71% per year, which indicates the increase of areas classified as non-forests.
As the forest cover data of FA 2010 is not retrieved for the analysis of deforestation rate in the target sites, the national deforestation rate (FA 2010) is used as baseline: 0.5% per annum.
The remote sensing analysis, conducted by RECFOTC in Aug 2014, covered the North Cardamom Mountains Landscape (NCML) in the provinces of Battambang (BTB), Kampong Chnnang (KCH), Kampong Speu (KSP) and Pursat (PUR). The Forest Cover map 2006 produced by Forest Administration (FA) has been used as baseline data. The dataset was compared with the FA2006 map to determine the change happened in the interval. Due to the extent of the area only a comparison only between the total figures were carried out at provincial level. The results of this analysis included change analysis or trend in deforestation rates at both provincial level and the target site level.

description.narrative:
Land area covered by degraded forest as % of total forest cover in target sites in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhang, Battambang and Pursat provinces.
[revised]

comment.narrative:
6.6%
[revised]

10% reduction in land covered by degraded forest relative to total forest cover by EoP.
[revised]

0.8% increase in land covered by degraded forest in the target areas.
Remote Sensing Analysis, RECOFTC, 2014:
-Land areas covered degraded forest at :
Target site = 7.4%
Land areas covered by degraded forest in the target sites had increased from 6.6% (Baseline, FA 2006) to current status of 7.4%; meaning there has been an increase of 0.8% in degraded forest in the target sites of the project; while the project aims to reduce the areas covered by degraded forest of 10%.
The project, with technical support from RECOFTC Chief Technical Advisor, conducted the remote sensing analysis to measure the deforestation rate and areas of degraded forests regarding the completion of project strategic result framework. Due to the limited scope of this assessment and the complex of technical issues, the study has defined the deforestation, within the context of the SFM project as the transformation from any forest types to non-forest areas, and the degradation forest has been identified as the transformation from Evergreen or Deciduous Forests to Other Forests.
Forestry Administration has yet identified the forest areas considering as degradation forests., due to the complex of technical issues and financial resources as required to measure the degraded forests. However, FA has assertively affirmed to conduct the assessment of degraded forests by 2016, as part of the REDD+ Strategy development.

Annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction (ER) due to adoption of improved cook stoves at the national level.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: ER=0
ER= 61,000t CO2e/year

The 2014 Annual ER from ICS at the national level is 690,177 tCO2e/year (GERES ICS project in Cambodia)
At the national level, 590,753 units were sold in 2014. The total ICS sold as of Dec 2014 was 1,126,626 units.

description.narrative:
No. of a. CFs and b. CPAs around the Cardamoms that have completed all legalization requirements to operate as an indirect result of SFM efforts in building capacity and policy approaches in government.
[revised]

comment.narrative:
a. 72 CFs have agreement with FA
b. 20 CPAs have developed a number of steps under CPA guidelines
[revised]

a. 125 CFs (53 additional) have agreement with FA by EoP.
b. 34 CPAs approved by EoP.
[revised]

a. 88 CFs, including 21 target CFs, of all 155 CF in the target provinces have been approved by MAFF (CFO/FA Statistic 2015). The project is continuing to support 13 target sites (09 CFs and 04 ACFM) to get approval from MAFF.
b. 25 CPAs (including 11 target CPAs) of all 35 CPAs in the target provinces were recognized by MOE. All 11 target CPA sties have been working on CPA management plan process, which expected to be fully completed by end of the project.

description.narrative:
Indices of forest resources and condition in target community-managed forests
[New]

comment.narrative: Inventory of forest resources in CFs and CPAs, undertaken at the start of the CF process.
Indices remain at 100% of baseline levels by EoP.

The assessment of forest resource inventory has been undertaken, which agreed during the project midterm review, as means to understand the indices of forest resources and conditions in the community-managed forests. However, the project is going to conduct the second forest inventory exercises in the target CF/CPA in order to assess if there is any changes of forest resources.
Result of Forest Inventory in 30 target CFs:
-Evergreen Forest: 671 Ha divided to 9 CFMP blocks
-Semi-Evergreen Forest: 966 Ha divided to 5 CFMP blocks
-Deciduous Forest: 8106 Ha divided to 78 CFMP blocks
-Non forested areas & grasslands: 1136 ha divided to 21 CFMP blocks
Result of Forest Inventory in 11 target CPA:
-Evergreen Forest: 372 Ha divided to 4 CFMP blocks
-Semi-Evergreen Forest: 966 Ha divided to 5 CFMP blocks,
-Deciduous Forest: 8106 Ha divided to 78 CFMP blocks
-Non-forested areas & grasslands: 1136 ha divided to 21 CFMP blocks

description.narrative: National capacities and tools exist to facilitate the widespread implementation of sustainable community-based forest management and technologies that reduce demand for fuel wood

comment.narrative: 12.5/33 ( see project document annex 14)
31/42 (see project document annex 14)

24/42

description.narrative:
a. Recommendation for amendment of existing guidelines (if needed) in NFP for CF for additional modalities and business enterprise plan.
b. Recommendation for guideline documents for CPAs
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
a. Legal framework for CFs (2006) exists, but they are still lacking for ACFMs, and for business enterprise plan.
b. CPA guidelines are in draft form.
[Revised]

a. CF framework amended to include the additional modalities of CF, and business enterprise development.
b. CPA guidelines revised with lessons from SFM project.
[Revised]

The concept notes of ACFM (PF, CBPF, CCF) and Business Plan of CF drafted and presented to FA and relevant stakeholders. The field demonstration cover 04 sites (02 PF, 01 CBPF, 01 CCF). The documentation of lessons learned from the pilot sites have been documented by RECOFTC, including the specific recommendation to FA for amendment of existing CF guideline.
b. MOE/DRCPAD had conducted series of sub-national consolation workshop to collect comment and feedback from relevant stakeholders on existing CPA guideline. Signification comment have raised included the revisions of roles and benefit of local community from the protect areas, to have self-sustain financing to continue protection and management of the CPA. The inputs and comment from workshops is going to presents and discuss in the national workshop, scheduling by end of the project.

description.narrative:
CLUP training module reflects SFM and energy by integrating CF and CPA development and sustainability.
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Land use planning by local authorities includes some attention to SFM, but needs more focused approach.
[Revised]

Improved CLUP training module incorporating SFM and energy approaches established at Provincial and District levels.
[Revised]

The issue of SFM and fuelwood energy have been included in the facilitation process of CLUP development.
The existing forests sites as well potential forest areas have been identified and included in the CLUP, as results, the target 5 CPA, 3CF, 1CCF, 2 PF integrated in CLUP process. The development of commune land used planning, which implemented in four target communes, had almost been completed. The provincial department of land management urban planning and construction is the leading government agency to develop the CLUP, which involved from various government institutions Department of Environment (DOE), Department of Agriculture (DpA), Forestry Administration Cantonment (FAC), Department of Mine and Energy, and commune council.

description.narrative:
Wood & Biomass Strategy drafted.
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Wood & Biomass Energy Strategy updated database in formulation and approved for implementation.
[Revised]

Wood & Biomass Strategy developed to the point of approval.
[Revised]

Ministry of Industry, Mine and Energy (MIME) were divided into two (02) ministries: Ministry of Industry and Handicraft (MIH) and Ministry of Mine Energy. The change of government structures had also affected the project activity. Up to early 2015, Ministry of Mine and Energy, the responsible agency, had renewed the Wood Energy Working Group (WEWG) to continue finalizing the Wood and Biomass Energy Strategy Action Plan. As result, the survey on wood energy consumption had been conducted in 05 selected provinces to updated database in the strategy formulation. And the two-day national consultation workshop was conducted with relevant stakeholders. Up to now, MME/General Department of Energy (GDE) has been working internally to review the draft WBES based on comment from the consultation workshop.

description.narrative:
Annual volume of sustainable fuel wood produced from the wood lots starting Year X
[Indicator has been deleted as a result of MTR recommendation and consideration by project board and RTA]

comment.narrative: 0 baseline to be established
[Indicator deleted]

description.narrative: Financial strategies in MAFF and MOE to support SFM, including opportunities for REDD and carbon financing for sustained funding to support community-based forestry by Year 4

comment.narrative: X Qtr Year 4

The project has made effort to support the policies reform, including the exploring funding opportunities for community protected areas to be able to extract income from the implementation of eco-system services through partnering with other development partners. And the project has supported MME for the updated Wood and Biomass Energy Strategy, which the promotion of green charcoal under the SFM project, has been included as one of the priority actions plan in the WBES.
As mentioned in the previous PIR Report, this activity is unlikely relevant to the project, but other UNDP supported project, UN-REDD and FCPF, have been working on this. Based on the updated progress of FCPF project, REDD+ strategy has been draft and revisions have been made following the series of technical consultation meetings with various stakeholders, including relevant government institutions and NGOs.
The project has called for proposals from NGO piloting the REDD+ related initiatives.

description.narrative: Financing generated from other funding sources (banks, green funds, etc.) by EOP

comment.narrative: Near zero

US$8,000
The project board recommended to use the data on Greenhouse gas emission reduction saved from ICS and charcoal under the SFM project. The SFM GHG ER monitoring report conducted by GERES showed that ER was of 30,894 tCO2 from the dissemination of 143,575 stoves and 17 operational ICK.
Under the SFM project, about 58 tons of green charcoals had been produced from the operation of 17 efficient charcoal kilns, as of Dec 2014, which approximately earned about $8,000.

description.narrative: Community-based sustainable forest management is being implemented effectively within a context of cantonment, province, district and commune level planning delivering concrete benefits to local communities

No. of FA cantonment and DOE provincial PA offices that have community-based forest management development plans by EOP.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: 0 provinces
4 provinces

Besides the target CF, all 04 FAC had worked with other development partners to establish CF management plan. The CFO data in 2015 showed that there are 155 CF in the four target provinces, and 66 CF of them have been supported by FAC and various NGO to establish the CF management plan.
All 30 CFMP are being finalized based on the final comment from FA. 4 ACFM have progressed step 8 (CF inventory). The management blocks has been conducted in 3 sites.
Out of the target 11 CPA in four provinces, DOE/PA in Battabang and Pursat have also supported other CPA for the management plan development (CPA data in 2014, DRCPAD). 11 CPAs had completed forest inventory. And result of forest inventory had already shared to local community. DOE/PA staff actively support CPAMC to prepare the CMPAMP and CMPBP. And the first draft CPAMP/CPMBP are ready by end of Q.3 2015.

description.narrative:
No. of CPAs with management plans and business plans that have passed final stage of approval process and are being implemented.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: 0 CPAs
10 CPAs have passed the final stage of approval proces by EoP

None of all 11 target CPAs have completed and approved the management and business plan. The current progress is likely to complete the CPA MP and BP by end of the project.
11 CPAs had completed forest inventory. And result of forest inventory had already shared to local community. DOE/PA staff actively support CPAMC to prepare the CMPAMP and CMPBP. And the first draft CPAMP/CPMBP are ready by end of Q.3 2015. As of June 2015, all 11 CPAs completely reached step 6 (natural resources assessment and forest inventory, study the customary use need of CPA, and drafting CPA management), which 5 of them completed this step.

description.narrative:
Number of CFs with management and business plans that have passed final stage of approval process and are being implemented.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: 0 CFs

a. 34 CFAs (including 30 CFs and 4 ACFMs) have passed the final stage of approval process by EoP.
[Revised]

All 30 target CF have reached final stage of management plan approval process; and are being implemented. 4 ACFM have progressed step 8 (CF inventory).
The CFMP of all 30 CF were draft and have been reviewed by FA technical team already. The detail plan of CFMP were carefully reviewed including the proposed annual activity plan, objective of management blocks, result of forest inventory, level of demand and supply of forest resources by local people. This review helped ensure the proper management of the forest resources. Up to now, 22 CFs have stated collecting forest resources, in particular non-forest timber products, in accordance the management plan and business plan.
22 FACs officer who attend TOT training participate SFM staff to facilitate CFMP & CFBP and ACFM implementation. 10 DOE &WS officer who attend TOT training have participated with SFM staffs to facilitate 11 CPAMP and 11 CF business plan.

description.narrative: No. of locally commune-based land use plan (CLUP) for SFM based on CF/CPA developed

comment.narrative: 4 CLUPs by EoP

Four (04) commune land use plans (CLUPs) for SFM developed.
All four CLUP books completely developed, and two of them got approval from provincial governors, while the remaining two CLUP books have been submitted to the provincial state land use committee. The issue of SFM have been included in the CLUP development process. The existing forests sties as well potential forest areas have been identified and included in the CLUP, as results, the target 5 CPA, 3CF, 1CCF, 2 PF and 2 WISDOM integrated in CLUP process.

Income derived from SFM by target households before implementation of the business plan

Increase in average annual income by 20% from the baseline level by EoP.

As of June 2015, most CF has earned income generation from forest based business including fuel wood, Bamboo, mushrooms, wild vegetables, red ants and traditional medicine, which provided benefited to about 1,169 CF members.
The formal assessment of income from forest based business to be conducted at EoP.

The specific case studies conducted by RECOFTC on the implementation of forest-based business in some selected CF has positively shown the improvement livelihood of poor community members.

description.narrative: No. of operational improved cook stove production centres

comment.narrative: 25 cluster
8 additional at EOP

08 ICS clusters, consisting of 45 producers, fully established (06 clusters in KCH, one in KSP, and one in PST) and operated the ICS production (including NKS and NLS stove).
It is noticed that major ICS production are in Kampong Chhnang province, where producers, distributors, are at Kampong Chhnang.
The ICS production plan of each producer were developed and regularly monitored to ensure the production of ICS is achievable.
The ICS monitoring data in May 2015 reported that all ICS were sold, as the demand of ICS has been notably increased.

description.narrative:
Average income of stove producers
[Revised]

comment.narrative: $40/month
$60/month by EoP

$86.53/month (Average income of stove producer)
(Re: GERES stove producers’ profitability assessment, Dec 2014).
As of June 2015, All 45 ICS production unit owners have increasingly employed local people up to 180 employees. And based on the income analysis of ICS, conducted by GERES, the income margin is about 800 riels ($0.2) per stove, and in average, the ICS employee could produce at least 30 stoves per day.

description.narrative: Partnership for Develpment Results (PfDR)
Better alignment of aid with national development priorities, greater mutual accountability, and innovative partnerships for CMDG attainment.
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division

(1) Sustainability of CRDB/CDC (2) No. of Technical Working Groups with funded and government-led PBA Action Plan (3) % of policy recommendations of most recent Aid Effectiveness Report implemented by TWGs within 12 months of publication

comment.narrative:
• 0 points for CDC/CRDB sustainability (2010) • 0 TWG funded and following government led PBA roadmaps (2010) • 42%* of policy recommendations of most recent AER (2010) implemented by TWGs
* Main recommendations in 2010 were: 1. PBA application (at least 5 TWGs can be thought to be moving ahead on this) 2. Networking and knowledge management (all TWGs joined the TWG Network meeting earlier in April – tho that is a bit lame as justification) 4. Influencing the global framework – all TWGs consulted on PD 5. Evaluation and many incorporated into JMIs 5. Joint monitoring – Education and Health are the only ones to really do this. D&D may follow. Taking each as 25%, I would give 7 + 10 + 20 + 5 = 42%.

1.1 Support RGC (CDC and Ministry of Environment) in establishing partnership mechanism and aid tracking system for monitoring climate change. 1.2 Prepare analytical reports and policy documents to guide development effectiveness work and DCPS implementation 1.3 Hold a consultation meeting with all TWGs to begin SDG localization and link TWGs work to broader development goals and partnership effort.

1.1 The ODA Database was modified to take account of climate change funding, including to add sectors for adaptation and mitigation as well as to align the recording of aid flows with the MoE Strategic Plan. Seminars were held with MoE, led by CDC staff, to discuss principles for partnership and dialogue; these informed the new Council on Sustainable Development and MoE outreach with DPs. 1.2 The project team supported the production of a new ODA data analysis detailing aid trends to Cambodia. A revised TWG guideline was also prepared based on the 2014 TWG performance review and was disseminated to all TWGs 1.3 A meeting of the TWG Network was held in October 2015 to discuss the SDGs, the Industrial Development Policy and the work of the TWGs.

1. 5 points - Capacity of the CMAA to lead the implementation of the NMAS annually - NMAS annual workplans (2 points) + progress reports (2 points) + NMAS integrated gender sensitive M&E system in place and endorsed by the TWG during Year 1 and sustained during Year 2-5 (1 point). 2. 10% reduction in the number of landmine casualties in Battambang, Banteay Meancheay and Pailin 3. 90% of annual tasks conducted in accordance with the MAPU work plan 4. 54% of beneficiaries from mine clearance that are women and PWD 5. 70 % of land cleared from mines annually through local planning process used for agriculture 6. 2 countries that benefit from Cambodia on demining

116 local NGOs/CBOs from 21 provinces 71 project partners, 47 local NGOs and 8 CBOs (52 NGO/CBOs) in 21 provinces, 59 districts, 113 communes and 428 villages can design a Community Based Adaptation (CBA) project and implement climate change adaptation projects.

1. NHDR report 2015 is finalized and launched 2. Competitiveness and Linkages in Cambodia's Manufacturing sector study report produced and disseminated. 3. Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Market Assessment completed to inform future energy programming of UNDP and the government. 4. Study on the utilization of social protection schemes by special vulnerable group in Cambodia (including PLHIV, KAP and Person with Disability) completed 5. 1. Draft of NHDR report 2015 was finalized and submitted for senior management review 2. Competitiveness and Linkages in Cambodia's Manufacturing sector study report finalised in Q2 and disseminated 3. Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Market Assessment completed in Q2 and disseminated. A one pager communications was prepared 4. Modalities for conducting the study on the utilization of social protection schemes by special vulnerable group in Cambodia (including PLHIV, KAP and Person with Disability) were assessed 5. A consultant to develop toolkit on empowering women affected by HIV to protect their rights was contracted in Dec. The toolkit is expected to complete in Q1 2016 6. Inputs were provided through the Social Protection Dialogues to the update of the National Social Protection Strategy 2011 - 2015 7. Questions on climate and disaster sensitive were included the ID Poor questionnaire. Due the issue in recruiting IT firm to modify the database, the next step to modify the ID Poor database was delayed

comment.narrative: 1.1 Line ministries have limited capacity to analyze their sector budget from results and gender perspective; Draft of GMAP of OCM available for consultation 1.2 Neary Rattanak III is not budgeted 1.3 Capacity Assessment of MoWA was conducted and the report was endorsed by MoWA 2.1 Training on gender equality sessions were provided by MoWA in past years 2.2 WDC staff have limited capacity on business development and management services 2.3 In 2010, 50 women and WDC staff were trained on market vocational skills on krama weaving and sewing 3.1 No

1.1 Five sector plans with gender-specific targets and budget allocation 1.2 1750 trainees (350 annually) of RSA civil servant trainees receiving training on gender equality by MoWA 1.3 Gender-sensitive curriculum of RSA developed 1.4 Capacity Development Strategy of MoWA developed 1.5 PBA on gender equality and partnership agreement drafted 2.1 Two WDCs are fully functioned 2.2 800 women trained on market oriented business and technical skills 3.1 Feasibility study report on establishment of One Stop Service Center 3.2 100% of population in 100 target villages who are aware that GBV is wrong and criminal act 3.3 300 village and commune chiefs, CWCC members, CSO representatives receiving TOT on GBV CCE skills and methodology

1.1 16 sector plans are gender-specific targets and budget allocation 1.2 1,007 students of the RSA and 440 newly recruited civil servants (274 females) 1.3 Gender-sensitive curriculum of RSA developed 1.4 Capacity Development Strategy of MoWA developed 1.5 PBA on gender equality and partnership agreement drafted2.1 1 (under planned 1 WDC due to the project review recommended would be phased out from service delivery to macro gender and economic policy) 2.2 71,839 women trained on market oriented business and technical skills. 3.1 Feasibility study report on establishment of One Stop Service Center was developed and shared to stakeholders 3.2 30% (under planned 70% due to the project review recommended would be phased out GBV service delivery and focus on national policy development documents: 2nd NAPVAW, OSS & P4P and follow up support) 3.3 7,2,00 participants received/participated in three initial workshops, four training of trainers, seven reflection trainings and 220 community conversations on GBV CCE skills and methodology.

comment.narrative: 1. District councils do not have a Local Government Association which represents them. 2. Insufficient systems and procedures for operation of Local Government Associations. 3. inputs/proposals into NCDD sub-committee debates have been addressed.

1.1 The Joint Secretariat operates in compliance with the newly established POMM 1.2 Long-term policy guidance and 5-year strategic plan 2016-2020 of new League of Local Association is developed 1.3 South-South cooperation through study tour/s aimed at enhancing the institutional capacity of the Associations of Sub-national Administration Councils are organized/ facilitated. 2.1 Grant provided to 6 PALC. 2.2 Code of Conduct for all sub-national administration councils/councilors disseminated 2.3 The Joint Secretariat has been able to take on increased roles and responsibilities in providing services to both Associations

1.1 - The POMM was officially approved by NLC Executive Committee and National Council in October 2015 and further approved by NACPC Executive Committee and National Council in December 2015. 1.2 5 year strategic plan is pending due to workload in 2015 to restructure secretariat, insufficient resources to prepare for the project extension 1.3 Cambodian LGA delegates participated in UCLG-ASPAC executive and council meeting in September 2015 at Wakatobi, Indonesia 2.1 Grants were provided to six Provincial Associations (PAs) starting in mid 2015. 2.2 The Code of Conduct for local (DMK-CS) councilors completed and approved by NLC executive committee with 16,000 copies printed and distributed to local councilors national wide. 2.3 he joint secretariat of two associations was established by endorsed by both executive committees of two associations in March 2015. Secretary General was officially appointed.

description.narrative: Cambodia Cassava Trilateral Assistance and DTIS Enhancement

title.narrative: China-Cambodia-UNDP Trilateral Cooperation Cassava Project Phase II

description.narrative: The project aims at bringing positive impact on poverty reduction/livelihood of the poor farmers in the sector through capacity building to meet cassava Chinese market requirement.
capital of a political entity

1. Need Assessment Study to understand the need and capacity gap of cassava farmers and processors/exporters produced 2. Environmental impact assessment produced 3. Package of technical knowledge produced to address the capacity gap and to provide low-cost environmental solution to farmers and processors/exporters 4. Linkage with Chinese market built 5. Cassava handbook produced to provide overview of the sector and requirement for production and export, this is for general user

comment.narrative: 1. Cassava sector profile providing overview of cassava sector produced by the Ministry of Commerce in 2010 2. Overview of cassava and its impact on environment produced under UNDP project in 2010 3. There no available full package of technical knowledge covering from the stage of cassava planation up to cassaa export 4. China and Cambodia already have good trade relation and Cambodia has exported some cassava to China already, but the export was not done on regular basis and there no direct link built between Cambodia supplier and Chinese buyers 5. Cassava sector profile providing overview of cassava sector produced by the Ministry of Commerce in 2010

5. Cassava handbook produced to provide overview of the sector and requirement for production and export, this is for general user
With the achievement of indicator number 3, UNDP also provide expanded support, with request from the Ministry of Agriculture Forestry and Fisheries of Cambodia, to 12 on-farm-demonstration field with the aim to help farmers apply knowledge gain on their farm land. the following indicators were set for this expanded support: 6. % of yield increment for cassava farmers in the 12 on-farm-demonstration fields 7. Availability of the stock of good cassava stem for the next year planation
Baseline: 6. Cassava farmers experience yield decrease all over the country (2014) 7. Not adequate supply of good cassava stem (free from disease) for plantation (2014)

5. Cassava handbook produced and published 6. As per the field monitoring visit in October 2015, there is positive sign of yield improvement in cassava of around 70% in average among all the 12 on-farm-demonstration fields. 7. N/A

title.narrative: Forest Carbon Partnership Facility REDD+ Readiness(FCPF)

description.narrative: Forest Carbon Partnership Facility REDD+ Readiness Project (FCPF)

title.narrative: Forest Carbon Partnership Facility REDD+ Readiness(FCPF)
Forest Carbon Partnership Facility REDD+ Readiness(FCPF)

description.narrative: Forest Carbon Partnership Facility

1. National REDD+ Readiness Coordination Mechanism Institutionalized 2. National REDD+ Readiness process is fully operationalized 3. Stakeholders are engaged and provided with information on REDD+ and the national REDD+ readiness process 4. National REDD+ Strategy is developed 5. REDD+ strategies of line agencies are developed 6. Report on valuation of co-benefits completed 7. An initial analysis of potential benefit sharing models completed 8. Initial analysis of existing funds workshops and meetings to discuss national options 9. Grievance mechanism is established 10. Information paper on a proposed approach to national safeguards is finalized 11. Development and institutionalization of National REDD+ intervention guidelines at sub-national level 12. Subnational framework for REDD+ implementation developed

comment.narrative: Baseline 2013 1. Interim REDD+ Taskforce established but not fully operationalized 2. Elements of national REDD+ readiness management established, but not fully operationalized 3. N/A 4. The process to develop national REDD+ strategy is initiated 5. Initial analyses of components of a national REDD+ strategy identified 6. N/A 7. N/A 8. N/A 9. N/A 10. N/A 11. Diversity of technical documents in draft stage and include policy brief on monitoring biodiversity co benefits; options paper on design of conservation trust funds; recommendations on new approaches to improve forest monitoring systems to address drivers of deforestation and forest degradation; and lessons learnt report on validation report underlines the complexity and challenge of validation demands 12. Existing REDD+ demonstration in two sites

1. National REDD+ Strategy finalized
2. National Protected Area Strategic Management Plan (NPASMP) finalized
3. 6 additional subnational REDD+ demonstration sites initiated

1. The final draft of the National Reducing Emission from Deforestation and Forest Degradation (REDD+) Strategy (NRS) has been developed. As integral components of the UNFCCC Warsaw Framework, the final draft of the National Forest Monitoring System (NFMS) and Forest Reference Emission Levels (FREL) have also been developed. The NRS, FREL and NFMS have been presented at the Conference of Parties COP 21 in Paris in December 2015.
2. The final draft of the National Protected Area Strategic Management Plan (NPASMP) 2016-2030 has been developed and is being reviewed for endorsement by the Ministry of Environment (MoE).
3. Significant progress was made to the implementation of REDD+ subnational activities in the two protected area sites with the General Department for the Administration of Nature Conservation and Protection (GDANCP); two sites with the Fisheries Administration (FiA); and one site with the Forestry Administration (FA). Field survey reports of the five proposed pilot are being finalized. The proposed list of priority drivers and measures to tackle divers has been generated and agreed with stakeholders. Prioritised measures implementation to address divers in the pilot sites started.

A national strategy, programme, and financing mechanism established for cohesive climate change response at national, sub-national and community levels.

Increase interaction and accountability of elected bodies and authorities to citizens through strengthened democratic processes at the national and sub-national levels.
Human rights affairs
Supporting Government implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Human rights affairs
Supporting Disabled People’s Organisations to raise the voice and protect the rights of people with disability
Human rights affairs

1. No. of advocacy strategies developed, based on strong evidence and implemented to influence government ministry and institution to develop disability inclusive policies 2. No. of persons with diverse disabilities, including women have increased participation in democratic processes 3. No. of advocacy strategies developed & implemented to influence key ministries to improve the implementation of disability law and UNCRPD on access to information, public accessibility, and access to employment 4. Increased awareness about the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) demonstrated by the general public 5. Increased awareness on disability rights & issues among targeted groups (general public, NGOs, government ministries, persons with disabilities, private sector, and Disabled People Organizations (DPOs)) 6. Increased awareness about UNCRPD among DPOs, key relevant ministries, disability NGOs and CSOs

comment.narrative: There is no data available for baseline.

1. 5 (1-One advocacy strategy developed for ministry of information to ensure disability is included into their policies and framework; 2-One advocacy strategy for National Election Committee developed; 3-Two disability advocacy statements developed and submitted to government for actions – disability type and classification policy, pension scheme for persons with disabilities; 4-One advocacy strategy for National Committee for Disaster Management developed) 2. 2,000 (45% are women with disabilities) persons with diverse disabilities participated in the democratic process (commune investment process) & 60% of members (136,000) are able to join the community activity and have rights/voices to make decision. 3. 5 (1-One advocacy strategy on information policy developed; 2- One advocacy strategy on election policy developed; 3- One advocacy strategy on disaster risk management developed; 4- 3 statements on improving the national disability and UNCRPD implementation – type and level of disability classification policy, pension scheme for persons with disabilities, job employment at private sector). 4. About 100,000 people will receive awareness on UNCRPD through IEC materials, radio programme and campaigns/forums. 5. 136, 000 received awareness on disability rights and those 40% are able to actively participate in awareness campaigns/forums. 6. 30% increase awareness about UNCRPD among DPOs, key relevant ministries, disability NGOs and CSOs.

description.narrative: Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Cambodia to support climate change resilient development and adaptation to climate change.
Strengthening climate information and early warning systems in Cambodia to support climate change resilient development and adaptation to climate change.

1.Number of national, sectoral and sub-national plans informed by accurate and up-to-date climate information 2.Effective and timely EW/climate information dissemination mechanism established and functioning 3.Number and type of targeted institutions/individuals with increased capacity to assimilate and forecast climate and environmental information 4.Number and type of training/learning tools on forecasting/modeling available for new hires or for continued learning of staff 5.Number and type of targeted institutions with increased capacity to reduce risks of and response to climate variability 6.Receipt of transboundary climate and weather related data 7.% change in agriculture productivity in select communities (data disaggregated by gender) 8.Number (national coverage) of automatic weather and climate monitoring network in Cambodia 9.Number and type of targeted individuals with increased capacity to provide O&M training for EWS related infrastructure 10.% of financing plan funded for hardware and software operations and maintenance

comment.narrative: 1.Climate and weather information currently provided by MOWRAM, but information is not sufficiently tailored to adequately inform planning 2.Early warning messages are disseminated, but roles, responsibilities and accountability not clear. No SOP in place. 3.9 forecasters at DOM (Staff do not currently serve as formal trainers, do not provide tailored products) 4.Training is generally provided by outside parties and is short term in nature. 5.Forecast information is currently provided, but not tailored. 6.Information sharing not systematized. 7.Early warnings provided are not tailored sufficiently to inform planning at agriculture household level 8.12 fully functional hydrological stations, 0 fully functional meteorological stations 9. Unclear as brand of equipment and related supplies that need to be procured 10.Currently O&M is funded by the MOWRAM budget, this is however insufficient. A financing plan is needed for the longer term sustainability of the network. This does not currently exist.
8.1. 67 functional hydrological stations (the 12 currently functional, plus the 55 as part of this project), up to 25 functional meteorological stations (2017 – 2018)

- Project inception workshop organized - Provincial workshop to consult with Provincial Department of Water Resources and Meteorology organized to identify their need of the hydro/met stations for all the 24 provinces, their preliminary capacity need is also identified - Draft map of the hydro/met stations in the country produced

title.narrative: Policy, Communications, and Social Innovations for Human

description.narrative: The project aims to contribute a Human Development perspective to the quality of public discourse, the design of policies, and the design of institutional capacity development strategies (including national programmes).

Manage the transition in composition of ODA and to expand access to other sources of global development financing.

title.narrative: Clearing for Results III- Mine Action for Human Dev't

description.narrative: Seeks to achieve 2 results: Contracting of mine action services to deliver 13 percentage of the total mine ERW contaminated areas impact free, and Establish a mine action programme performance monitoring system that measures human development outcomes.

Clearing poorest mines/ERW contaminated areas and establish a mine action programme performance monitoring system that that measures human development outcomes and progress towards achieving the status of free from the impact of mines/ERW for Cambodia.
policy, planning and administration
